final_answer:
The humor and satire in this image come from the irony and contrast it presents. 

On the left side, a figure is clearly excited to hold a "FastPass" ticket, which promises quicker access or bypassing regular lines, suggesting a sense of privilege or expedited experience.

However, the right side humorously contradicts this expectation by showing a large crowd waiting at the "FastPass Entrance," implying that the special ticket doesn’t actually provide a faster or exclusive experience. 

The juxtaposition emphasizes the futility and possible absurdity of such "fast passes" when they become so common that they no longer offer the intended benefit. This plays on the general frustration and skepticism people may have about the effectiveness of these kinds of express entries, making it both funny and a bit satirical.
ground_truth: The image is ironic, because fast pass entrance was meant for people to pass the gate fast but as more no. of people bought the pass due to which the queue has become longer and it becomes slow and time consuming
